natural solution: Since the ant starts at the top vertex, his next destination, vertex A, is equally likely to be any of the 4 vertices along the middle ring. Each of these vertices is adjacent to 4 other vertices, and since they are in the middle, exactly 1 of those 4 vertices is the bottom vertex.
So, regardless of which intermediate vertex he goes to, the ant will end up at the bottom vertex with $\boxed{\frac{1}{4}}$ probability, by the symmetry of the 4 intermediate stages.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes ant_walks :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "ant_walks 0 = 1"
and h1 : "ant_walks (Suc n) = 4 * ant_walks n"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. ant_walks n = 4 ^ n"
shows  "ant_walks 2 / ant_walks 1 = 1 / 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An octahedron consists of two square-based pyramids glued together along their square bases to form a polyhedron with eight faces. Imagine an ant that begins at the top vertex and walks to one of the four adjacent vertices that he randomly selects and calls vertex A. From vertex A, he will then walk to one of the four adjacent vertices that he randomly selects and calls vertex B. What is the probability that vertex B will be the bottom vertex? Express your answer as a common fraction.

[asy]
draw((-10,0)--(10,0)--(3,-15)--cycle);
draw((-10,0)--(10,0)--(3,15)--cycle);
draw((10,0)--(17,7)--(3,-15)--(17,7)--(3,15));
draw((-3,7)--(3,15)--(-3,7)--(17,7)--(-3,7)--(-10,0)--(-3,7)--(3,-15),dashed);
[/asy] The final Answer is \frac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Since the ant starts at the top vertex, his next destination, vertex A, is equally likely to be any of the 4 vertices along the middle ring. Each of these vertices is adjacent to 4 other vertices, and since they are in the middle, exactly 1 of those 4 vertices is the bottom vertex.
 So, regardless of which intermediate vertex he goes to, the ant will end up at the bottom vertex with $\boxed{\frac{1}{4}}$ probability, by the symmetry of the 4 intermediate stages.
 *)

theorem
fixes ant_walks :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "ant_walks 0 = 1"
and h1 : "ant_walks (Suc n) = 4 * ant_walks n"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. ant_walks n = 4 ^ n"
shows  "ant_walks 2 / ant_walks 1 = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: An ant starts at point A and walks in a straight line. At each step, it covers a distance equal to four times the distance it covered in the previous step. The distance covered in the first step is 1 unit. What is the ratio of the distance covered in the second step to the distance covered in the first step? The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

shows  "\<exists> A B. A \<noteq> B \<and> (\<forall> choices. choices = 4 \<longrightarrow> (1 / choices) * (1 / (choices - 1)) = probability)"

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = 1 / 4"
shows  "\<exists> A B. A \<noteq> B \<and> (\<forall> choices. choices = 4 \<longrightarrow> (1 / choices) * (1 / (choices - 1)) = probability)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Suppose there is a probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. Find two distinct numbers $A$ and $B$ such that for any set of 4 choices, the probability of picking two different elements is $\frac{1}{A} \cdot \frac{1}{B - 1} = \frac{1}{4}$.

shows  "prob_ant_path (1, 4, 1) = 1 / 4"

draw((-3,7)--(3,15)--(-3,7)--(17,7)--(-3,7)--(-10,0)--(-3,7)--(3,-15),dashed);
[/asy] The final Answer is \frac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Since the ant starts at the top vertex, his next destination, vertex A, is equally likely to be any of the 4 vertices along the middle ring. Each of these vertices is adjacent to 4 other vertices, and since they are in the middle, exactly 1 of those 4 vertices is the bottom vertex.
 So, regardless of which intermediate vertex he goes to, the ant will end up at the bottom vertex with $\boxed{\frac{1}{4}}$ probability, by the symmetry of the 4 intermediate stages.
 *)

theorem
fixes top_vertex adjacent_vertices bottom_vertex :: nat
assumes h0 : "top_vertex = 1"
and h1 : "adjacent_vertices = 4"
and h2 : "bottom_vertex = 1"
and h3 : "prob_ant_path (top_vertex, adjacent_vertices, bottom_vertex) = 1 / 4"
shows  "prob_ant_path (1, 4, 1) = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: An ant is on a triangular grid with 1 vertex on the top, 4 adjacent vertices in the middle, and 1 vertex on the bottom. The ant has an equal probability of choosing any of the adjacent vertices from the top vertex. Find the probability that the ant reaches the bottom vertex after passing through the middle layer. The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

assumes h0 : "P_top = 1"
and h1 : "P_A = P_top / 4"

a_8.informal problem: If the probability of an event A happening is one-fourth the probability of a top event, and the probability of an event B happening is one-fourth the probability of event A, and the probability of the top event is 1, what is the probability of event B happening? The final answer is $\frac{1}{4^4}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>A B. 1 / (real (card (adjacent_vertices A)) * real (card (adjacent_vertices B))))"
shows  "probability top_vertex bottom_vertex = 1 / 4"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An octahedron consists of two square-based pyramids glued together along their square bases to form a polyhedron with eight faces. Imagine an ant that begins at the top vertex and walks to one of the four adjacent vertices that he randomly selects and calls vertex A. From vertex A, he will then walk to one of the four adjacent vertices that he randomly selects and calls vertex B. What is the probability that vertex B will be the bottom vertex? draw((10,0)--(17,7)--(3,-15)--(17,7)--(3,15));
draw((-3,7)--(3,15)--(-3,7)--(17,7)--(-3,7)--(-10,0)--(-3,7)--(3,-15),dashed);
[/asy] The final Answer is \frac{1}{4}
 ### Proof
 Since the ant starts at the top vertex, his next destination, vertex A, is equally likely to be any of the 4 vertices along the middle ring. Each of these vertices is adjacent to 4 other vertices, and since they are in the middle, exactly 1 of those 4 vertices is the bottom vertex.
 So, regardless of which intermediate vertex he goes to, the ant will end up at the bottom vertex with $\boxed{\frac{1}{4}}$ probability, by the symmetry of the 4 intermediate stages.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>A B. 1 / (real (card (adjacent_vertices A)) * real (card (adjacent_vertices B))))"
shows  "probability top_vertex bottom_vertex = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a graph with vertices A and B, the probability is defined as $\frac{1}{(|A| \times |B|)}$, where $|A|$ and $|B|$ are the number of adjacent vertices to vertex A and vertex B, respectively. Find the probability between the top vertex and the bottom vertex if their product of adjacent vertices is 4. The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.
